div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF SEVENTY-SIX HINDOO ALIENS.
PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.
TO THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, IN AND FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON:

The petition of Moola Singh, Talok Singh, Dalip Singh, Bhagwan Singh, Pala Singh, Ala Singh, Biahsn Singh, Rulia Singh, Kishan Singh, Harijan Singh, Arjan Singh, Hire Singh, Bhag Singh, Amarao Singh, Duvan Singh, Puran Singh, Nuarang Singh, Dalip Singh, Vir Singh, Ratan Singh, Nama Singh, Bishan Singh, Bishan Singh, Rem Singh, Baboo Singh, Bhagat Singh, Thakar Singh, Variam Singh, Harnam Singh, Gurdit Singh, Kishan Singh, Gurbakhoh Singh, Khazan Singh, Paren Singh, Milkha Singh, Narnam Singh, Munshi Singh, Varian Singh, Sham Singh, Kakoo Singh, Basant Singh, Pooran Singh, Sher Singh, Santa Singh, Harnam Singh, Munshi Singh, Parem Singh, Partap Singh, Naurang Singh, Farzona Ali, Ahas Ali, Bahadar Shah, Mir Ahdylla, Nizam Din, Sultan Ali, Bagh Ali, Niaz Mohd, Rahmat Alla, Nayat Kahn, Amir Rhan, Amir Khan, Mohd Alam, Isay Khan, Amarat Khan, Sanday Khan, Shali Khar Khan, Namdar Khan, Gulam Modh, Sanday Khan, Baggn Khan, Umar Den, Ali But, Hanz Mohd, Chiragh Din, Madda Din, Ibrahim Din, Ismail Din, Rahmat Ali, Noor Khan, and Ishar Singh, respectfully shows;
I.

That your petitioners are former residents of the Philippine Islands and are at this time unlawfully
detained by the immigration authorities at the immigration station, Seattle, Washington.
II.

That you petitioners were lawfully admitted at a regular immigration port of entry, Manila, Philippine Islands; were duly examined by an immigration board and duly examined by medical officers of the United States government, and passed by said immigration officials at the said city of Manila, as being fit and proper persons to land in the territory held and controled by the United States government, and being strong and healthy enough and free from disease, to be entitled to pass the medical officers of the said immigration department. Said immigrants were duly landed and lives from varying periods from several months to several years in the city of Manila, and in the Philippine Islands, with the knowledge of the United States government.
III.

That you petitioners are now imprisoned and restrained of their liberty and detained by color of the authority of the United States in the custody of the Commissioner of Immigration, Seattle, Washington, at the immigration detention house in said city.
IV.

That the sole claim or authority, by virtue of which the said commissioner of immigration has restrained and detains your petitioners is a certain warrant of arrest based upon Section 20 of the Act of February 20, 1907, as amended by the Acts of March 26, 1910 and March 4, 1913, which warrant was issued contrary to law and without any foundation in law, and which even cites to be a fact that the aliens entered the United States in violation of law, which is not true, and of which faact, no proof has ever been offered. The other facts set out in said warrant or unlawful issue are untrue and not a cintilla of evidence has been introduced or presented to the Secretary or his assistant, who has ordered the aliens deported.
V.

That the aliens and your petitioners represent that they were not given a fair and impartial hearing, as is contemplated by law. That the immigration officals and inspectors were biased and prejudiced, which facts can be shown by affidavits or viva voce testimony, if they are given permission to be heard by this honorable court. That the government sent certain testimony to Washington, which your petitioners have been given no opportunity to answer. That new testimony can be produced showing that it would be an absolute impossibility for these men to become public charges, and showing that there never has been a time since their landing on the soil of the United States when they were even likely to become public charges. These petitioners have had their constitutional gaurantee denied them, and the entire proceeding from the landing of the petitioners on the Steamship Minnesota, has
been a proceeding conducted not in accordance with law. That the authority so called, exercised by the commissioner of immigration, Seattle, the comissioner general of immigration and the secretary of labor, have not been fairly exercised, in justice, or in accordance with law; said officials have not acted within the jurisdiction conferred upon them or in accordance with the provision of the act affecting such cases. The government has contended that these men violated some law on entering, which is not true, and there has never been any evidence before any of the government officials showing any violation of law, but there is much evidence showing a proper landing, the inspection and examination of the aliens, in accordance with law. No evidence showing the condition of the aliens when they were examined the first time in Manila, has been produced. The aliens, having once been examined, in accordance with law, and passed, the second attempted examination is improper, and not in accordance with law, and in direct violation of the Act of February 20, 1907, as amended. The allegation was made by the government, that these men unlawfully entered the United States, but this fact was not proven and is not true. That your petitioners are not alien immigrants, within the meaning of the Act, having entered under a previous proper examination at Manila. Your petitioners produced evidence which was not met by the government, which positively proves that the government's contention was untrue.
VI.

That the issuing of the warrant, the holding
of the examination by the by the immigration board at Seattle and on the Steamship Minnesota, the decision of the board at Seattle, and the decision of the Secretary of Labor, or his representative in denying the rights of your petitioners to land at Seattle, was all contrary to law and in direct violation of the Act of February 20, 1907, as amended.
VII.

That there was an abuse of authority on the part of the immigration board, and the commissioner of immigration at Seattle and the Secretary of Labor, or his representative at Washington, in denying your petitioners the right to land at Seattle, as there is absolutely no evidence upon which to base a decision
VIII.

That your petitioners' imprisonment, restraint and detention are in violation of their rights, privleges, and immunities, under the constitution and laws of the United States for the following reasons;
First; That your petitioners had once been duly examined and passed and could not lawfully be again examined, in accordance with law.

Second; The issuing of the warrant was contrary to law, and especially contracy to the act of February 20, 1907, as amended by the Act of March 4, 1913, for the reason that your petitioners had never become charges and had showed no liklihood of becoming charges, but on the other hand having affirmatively shown that there was no liklihood of their ever becoming charges.

That these men were examined at Manila under authority of the act of February 20, 1907, and if so, that examination was final and the second examination at Seattle improper, unless the government saw fit to arrest these men under authority of Section 20 of said act, which section makes the entire proceeding illegal and improper, as appears on the face of said section as the wording of that section is mandatory and does not deal in possibilities which the government is contending for.
IX.

That there was no evidence before the Immigration Board, the Commissioner of the Secretary, upon which to base the ruling of the board in rejecting the petitioners, and in requesting warrants, or the secretary, in ordering the aliens deported.
X.

The aliens resided, some of them as long as two years in the Philippine Islands and never became public charges or showed any liklihood of becoming charges, and as they were taken in custody immediately upon arrival of the vessel, and as they have been detained ever since their arrival, it cannot be said that they have become charges, as they have been in custody ever since leaving Manila, and they have never had an opportunity to show the fallact of the government's position.
XI.

In the case of the other aliens who came over with these petitioners, an alleged rehearing was granted, which was not rehearing at all, as the aliens were not permitted to be represented by friends or counsel, and
were not permitted to cross examine witnesses or to have any of the other privileges usual in these cases, and although those other aliens had taken an appeal, without giving proper consideration or accordance with law to those appeals, a medical examination was had and the appeal in those cases ignored. The aliens have been denied the privilege of seeing their friends and relatives, even within the bounds of reasonable restrictions, as can be shown by competent testimony.
XII.

The aliens have been housed together in a place only large enough for a third of their number and in a place where the cubical air space is only a third or fourth what it should be in keeping with healthful and sanitary conditions. The second examination of these men was improper as the Secretary, in a similar case ruled less than a year ago that men who had been once examined in Manila were not subject to reexamination in this country. The government has ruled that the Great Northern Steamship Company should in this case be relieved of deporting these aliens back to the place of embarkation, and that the government would defer this expense, showing the government's admission of their own error in once admitting the aliens and now again attempting to re-examine, as, in accordance with the Act of February 20, 1907, the Steamship Company should defer the expenses of the deportation.
XIII.

The Act of February 20th, 1907, provides that the headtax of Four Dollars ($4.00) for every alien entering
the United States shall be collected. These men paid this head-tax when they were examined in Manila, and were not compelled to pay the same on their arrival in Seattle, this provision and the law indicating that the men are supposed to pay this fee but once, and by inference they are not supposed to be examined more than once. The Act itself specifically provides that it is to apply to and regulate the immigration of aliens into the United States.

Section Six (6) of the Act of February 20th, provides that this Section was not applied to the states or territories, the District of Columbia, or places subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.
By referring to Section Twelve (12) and the last ten lines thereof, it will be noted that aliens coming from points in the United States are treated differently from those coming from foreign ports.

Section Thirty-three (33) provides that for the purpose of the Act above quoted the word "United States" shall be construed to mean the United States and any waters, territory or other place subject to the jurisdiction thereof, except the Isthmian Canal only.
XIV.

It will be noted by referring to page twenty-eight (28) of the Regulation of July 1, 1907, paragraph "G" thereof, that the aliens who have come from contiguous territory in the United States, namely from Manila, are subjected to different disposition than those
who have come from a foreign port.
XV.

It will be noted that this case makes the present cases very strong, indeed, from the alien standpoint, as the present cases do not come within the confines of this decision or of numerous other decisions, which hold the same as this one. The cases holding that the government must show that the men have become public charges within a year, and in absence of such a showing, they having been under the flag for a year throws the presumption against the government in that they have not become charges, and therefore, the probability is not only very remote, but becomes almost an impossibility. This I believe would be the holding of the Supreme Court, if we appealed and took the matter before the Circuit Court or that tribunal.
XVI.

Sub-division 4 of Rule 14, simply a ruling of the department, provides that the failure to present a certificate shall be deemed presumptive evidence that an examination has not occured. That presumption is only a presumption, however, and when the men testify under oath that they were examined and passed, and the government does not meet that definite testimony, than the presumption falls and their testimony under oath stands inasmuch as they can be punished for false swearing.
XVII
The Commissioner of Immigration is threatening unless restrained to deport these petitioners on authority of warrants which were improperly issued and have no basis in law.
XVIII.

That three of the aliens, Moola Singh, Ram Singh, and Ali Bux held certificates showing that they had been examined in Manila, but lost the same, either in boarding the boat or on the boat coming from Manila. That Boggu Khan had a certificate and lost the same coming from Manila, but by reason of the fact that he was not asked the question, did not testify in his examination of this fact, and can not be only prove conclusively, but the government's records in Manila in this case as in the other three will show this to be a fact and it can be proven to competent testimony.
IX.

That a copy of the warrants is not attached hereto for the reason that the same is entransit and to save the government's time and by agreement with the United States Immigration officals, this order is asked on the strength of a telegram received from a J.B. Densmore, acting Secretary of Labor, advising that warrants were being mailed for the return of seventy-three persons, whose names are not definitely known.
XX.
That the warrants issued are fatally defective in that they do not comply with law and in particular do not comply with the Act of February 20, 1907 as amended.
XXI.
That the aliens are not amenable to the law which is the basis for the issuance of these warrants.
XXII.
That the petitioners have had no hearing on the ground on which the exclusion is based.
XXIII.
That the Secretary of Labor, rendering the decisions in these cases, has violated the law, and particularly the Act of February 20, 1907 as amended by the Acts of March 26, 1910 and March 4, 1913.
XXXIV.

This honorable court has jurisdiction for the reason that there is a question of law involved, whether the aliens herein are amenable to the Act of February 20, 1907, as the aliens are herein claiming that they are not within the inhibition of the statutes.
XXV.
In some of the cases the petitioners had resided in the territory of the United States for more than one year and therefore the government was barred from proceeding in these cases.

WHEREFORE your petitioners pray that a writ of habeas corpus directing the immigration officals to bring the said alien petitioners in court and to show cause of their detention, or for an order to show cause directing the immigration officals to appear in court on a day certain to answer the petition herein filed, and to show cause why the said petitioners should not be discharged and no longer held.
Your petitioners further pray that they may be discharged from custody and released as being improperly held, and for such other and further relief as to the court may seem just and proper.
HINDOO ALIENS,
BY Herbert W. Meyers Attorney for aliens and petitioners.
